entry.value:
[{"id":"ST-786","entityId":"64-9541","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"ST"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"786"},{"name":"summary","value":"Find a way to get logger names and levels in the syslog-managed log file"},{"name":"description","value":"
When the spdlog logger is configured to use the syslog log sink class, it discards the logger name, which does not appear in the resulting log file.

The logger names are a very important source of diagnostic information. I think it is worth the time to figure out some way, no matter how ugly it may be, to get the logger names into the syslog file.

We are already using the spdlog-provided mechanism for specifying the content of every log line, and we are telling it to include the logger name. spdlog must have code that bypasses this configuration when using the syslog sink. Since we don't want to change the spdlog code itself, we will probably have to do something ugly like explicitly prepending the logger name to the log string. I hope there is another hook in the spdlog API that gives us an opportunity to do so.


Edit: Now that I have the syslog destination running on my machine, I see that the log level also does not appear in the log file. If anything, this is even more important than the logger name. I really need both of them to appear in the log file.
"},{"name":"created","value":"1535640102924"},{"name":"updated","value":"1536765291626"},{"name":"updaterName","value":"jsnead"},{"name":"updaterFullName","value":"Jerry Snead"},{"name":"resolved","value":"1536599516834"},{"name":"reporterName","value":"tcrews"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Tim Crews"},{"name":"commentsCount","value":"9"},{"name":"votes","value":"0"},{"name":"links","value":[{"value":"ST-532","type":"Subtask","role":"subtask of"}]},{"name":"Priority","value":["Normal"],"valueId":["Normal"],"color":{"bg":"#e6f6cf","fg":"#4da400"}},{"name":"Type","value":["Task"],"valueId":["Task"],"color":null},{"name":"State","value":["Verified"],"valueId":["Verified"],"color":{"bg":"#409600","fg":"#fff"}},{"name":"Assignee","value":[{"value":"tmclachlan","fullName":"Tyler McLachlan"}]},{"name":"Milestone","value":["2018 09 07"],"valueId":["2018 09 2018-09-11 16-20-04.png","id":"70-8238","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/Screenshot%20from%202018-09-11%2016-20-04.png?file=70-8238&c=true"},{"value":"Screenshot from 2018-09-11 16-21-41.png","id":"70-8239","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/Screenshot%20from%202018-09-11%2016-21-41.png?file=70-8239&c=true"},{"value":"Screenshot from 2018-09-12 08-02-06.png","id":"70-8242","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/Screenshot%20from%202018-09-12%2008-02-06.png?file=70-8242&c=true"},{"value":"Screenshot from 2018-09-12 08-11-34.png","id":"70-8243","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/Screenshot%20from%202018-09-12%2008-11-34.png?file=70-8243&c=true"},{"value":"Screenshot from 2018-09-12 08-11-44.png","id":"70-8244","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/Screenshot%20from%202018-09-12%2008-11-44.png?file=70-8244&c=true"},{"value":"Screenshot from 2018-09-12 08-13-09.png","id":"70-8245","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/Screenshot%20from%202018-09-12%2008-13-09.png?file=70-8245&c=true"}]}],"comment":[{"id":"69-17530","author":"abontrager","authorFullName":"Austyn Bontrager","issueId":"ST-786","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
syslog can be configured to include the log level.

spdlog passes the logger name to the syslog sink as it initializes syslog. When we open several loggers, it basically reinitializes syslog with a new logger name each time, leaving the last configured logger name as the only one which is used. To get different logger names to syslog, we somehow need to include them in the message.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1536088661623,"updated":1536088695740,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17778","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-786","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Jerry Snead, to verify this, look at /var/log/uls-control.log. Each line of the log file should contain two entries surrounded by square brackets, like this:

Sep 10 11:46:21 [camera] [trace] Failed camera I/O is not fatal because it has only been 1 seconds since the last successful communication

The first bracketed entry is the logger name. The second bracketed entry is the log level.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1536604966823,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17820","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-786","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Tim Crews Logging is correct (attached). However, I am using the standalone pc I just ran a job on and the log file was actually here: /var/opt/uls-control/control
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1536708141319,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17824","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-786","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Ah, a new twist: The standalone PC configuration. Unfortunately, if the log file you found was in /var/op/uls-control/control.log, this wasn't testing the new code we wrote for syslog at all.

It looks like I need to modify the Debian package configuration for the standalone PC to set up the syslog destination for logging, the same way we did for the embedded PC configuration. I just committed that change and kicked off a new installer.

I've also added another note to ST-795 that this is another PC that needs to be configured to use syslog as its logging destination. Until that PC is properly configured, it can't be used to verify ST-786.

(Jerry Snead, if you want to configure it yourself, edit the file /var/opt/uls-control/LSMSettings.ini. In the [LogDestinations] section, if the word "file" occurs anywhere, change it to "syslog".]
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1536751087651,"updated":1536762083450,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17829","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-786","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Loaded the .351 driver on the standalone pc - no /var/log/uls-control.log shows up.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1536764539124,"updated":1536708141319,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17830","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-786","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Jerry Snead, the standalone PC is apparently configured to use the "file" LogDestination. The installer will not change this, so you have to hand-edit LSMSettings.ini as described in my previous note and restart the control service.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1536764788679,"updated":1536751087651,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17831","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-786","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
With the .351 driver on the embedded pc, I do see /var/log/uls-control.log. I can open this file and view it and it shows good info (double brackets) and everything listed is up to date. I am closing this as verified fixed and will open a new low priority bug for the standalone pc.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1536764872951,"updated":1536764539124,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17832","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-786","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Jerry Snead, I don't think there are any new bugs with the standalone PC. All PCs, including the standalone PC, need to be re-configured (by hand) to use the syslog logger. This is already the subject of ST-795.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1536765168136,"updated":1536764788679,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17833","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-786","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Per Tim's note of 2018.09.12.0806. I have edited the /var/opt/uls-control/LSMSettings.ini file. The /var/log/uls-control.log now appears and has updated info on the standalone pc.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1536765291626,"updated":1536764872951,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]}],"tag":[]}, {"id":"ST-795","entityId":"64-9574","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"ST"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"795"},{"name":"summary","value":"Configure all lab machines to use the "syslog" logging destination"},{"name":"description","value":"
Currently some machines are using the "file" destination, which puts log files in /var/opt/uls-control/control.log, but others are using the "syslog" destination, which puts them in /var/log/uls-control.log. This discrepancy is making it hard to get good log data attached to YouTrack issues. We are often getting attached control.log files with weeks-old log data.

Once the changes for ST-786 are merged to trunk, the syslog destination will be better than the file destination in every way. Even before those changes are merged, I still think it is preferable to eliminate the ongoing confusion.

Someone will need to be on-site to make this configuration change. It will just take a minute at each site.
"},{"name":"created","value":"1536161153298"},{"name":"updated","value":"1536751218848"},{"name":"updaterName","value":"tcrews"},{"name":"updaterFullName","value":"Tim Crews"},{"name":"reporterName","value":"tcrews"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Tim Crews"},{"name":"commentsCount","value":"5"},{"name":"votes","value":"0"},{"name":"links","value":[{"value":"ST-532","type":"Subtask","role":"subtask of"}]},{"name":"Priority","value":["Normal"],"valueId":["Normal"],"color":{"bg":"#e6f6cf","fg":"#4da400"}},{"name":"Type","value":["Task"],"valueId":["Task"],"color":null},{"name":"State","value":["In Progress"],"valueId":["In Progress"],"color":{"bg":"#fed74a","fg":"#444"}},{"name":"Assignee","value":[{"value":"ajones","fullName":"Aaron Jones"}]},{"name":"Milestone","value":["2018 09 07"],"valueId":["2018 09 07"],"color":null}],"comment":[{"id":"69-17724","author":"ajones","authorFullName":"Aaron Jones","issueId":"ST-795","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I just changed the lab3 machine to write to syslog (it was file+console before). Heads up Jerry Snead, the log on that machine will now be /var/log/uls-control.log.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1536271024839,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17725","author":"ajones","authorFullName":"Aaron Jones","issueId":"ST-795","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I'm not sure how the paradise ultra is configured. I'll check next time I'm over there.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1536271089564,"updated":1536271024824,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17728","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-795","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Aaron Jones, Tyler just committed his syslog-related changes, so if you like, you can now configure the [LogDestinations] section for "syslog+console". I have tested this and it works.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1536271332021,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17740","author":"ajones","authorFullName":"Aaron Jones","issueId":"ST-795","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
That's awesome! Good job Tyler.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1536276678571,"updated":1536271089533,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17825","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-795","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Whatever PC Jerry refers to as "the standalone PC" also needs to be configured to use syslog as the log destination. I don't know how many other computers there are out there in the wild; I only learned of the standalone PC due to Jerry's verification note for ST-786. [Edit: Jerry has reconfigured that PC now.]

All PCs that are used for testing need syslog selected as their log destination, embedded PCs, standalone PCs, and developer's PCs. The "file" log destination serves no useful purpose anymore on Linux, and we keep wasting time chasing the wrong log files. (Jerry's attempt at verifying ST-786 was another waste of time.) I am tempted to just edit Logging.cpp to always use "syslog" instead of "file" on the Linux platform.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1536751218848,"updated":1536765459655,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]}],"tag":[]}, {"id":"ST-780","entityId":"64-9520","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"ST"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"780"},{"name":"summary","value":"Control.log not being written to."},{"name":"description","value":"
Tim Crews asked me to delete the control log this morning (ST-772), which I did. I just noticed it is empty. Nothing is being written to the control log today. (based on Tim's comments from ST-772 this has been going on since at least yesterday.
"},{"name":"created","value":"1535560909655"},{"name":"updated","value":"1536161214450"},{"name":"updaterName","value":"tcrews"},{"name":"updaterFullName","value":"Tim Crews"},{"name":"resolved","value":"1535567944042"},{"name":"reporterName","value":"jsnead"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Jerry Snead"},{"name":"commentsCount","value":"14"},{"name":"votes","value":"0"},{"name":"links","value":[{"value":"ST-532","type":"Subtask","role":"subtask of"},{"value":"ST-772","type":"Relates","role":"relates to"}]},{"name":"Priority","value":["Major"],"valueId":["Major"],"color":{"bg":"#ffee9c","fg":"#b45f06"}},{"name":"Type","value":["Bug"],"valueId":["Bug"],"color":null},{"name":"State","value":["Obsolete"],"valueId":["Obsolete"],"color":{"bg":"#b7e281","fg":"#444"}},{"name":"Assignee","value":[{"value":"tcrews","fullName":"Tim Crews"}]},{"name":"Milestone","value":["2018 08 24"],"valueId":["2018 08 24"],"color":null},{"name":"attachments","value":[{"value":"control.log","id":"70-8137","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/control.log?file=70-8137&c=true"},{"value":"LSMSettings.ini","id":"70-8138","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/LSMSettings.ini?file=70-8138&c=true"}]}],"comment":[{"id":"69-17402","author":"Miles","authorFullName":"Miles McNerney","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Here's the LSMSettings.ini, I'd think we'd get some debug messages anyway



[LogLevel]
default = debug
camera = trace
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535561131850,"updated":1535561174844,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17403","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Miles McNerney Tim Crews does ST-772 (weird JSON & BIN not matching error message) a symptom of this issue?
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535561260442,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17407","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
No, ST-772 is definitely not related to this issue.

Jerry, the log file is no longer located at /var/opt/uls-control/control.log. It is located at /var/log/uls-control.log.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535562197371,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17410","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
We should stop a "control.log" from being made @ /var/opt/uls-control then.

I will make a note to start using the /var/log/uls-control.log
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535562411529,"updated":1535561260442,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17412","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I agree; I will look into that.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535563315415,"updated":1535562197371,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17413","author":"Miles","authorFullName":"Miles McNerney","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
There's a uls-control.log at that location w/data. But it's not showing up in the GUI
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535563356209,"updated":1535561131834,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17414","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Ah, the LSM needs to be updated with this new location. The tricky part is, the destination of the log file is configurable at run-time (based on the [LogDestination] settings in LSMSettings.ini), and the LSM currently has no way of knowing that configuration.

But if the default configuration (controlled by the .deb package installer) is to log to the syslog (/var/log/uls-control.log), it seems that the LSM default should be to use that same location.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535563632611,"updated":1535563315415,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17415","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Once the /var/opt/uls-control/control.log is no longer being generated and this issue is toggled to fixed, I will verify the fix and close it out. Downgrading to Major from Release Critical.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535563862838,"updated":1535562411529,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17420","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I changed the code so it does not open control.log if the [LogDestinations] section does not specify "file" for any logger. This will be the case for the default installation (e.g. in Lab 3). So you shouldn't see /var/opt/uls-control/control.log anymore.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535567936305,"updated":1535563632611,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17421","author":"ajones","authorFullName":"Aaron Jones","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I just looked at ULTRA-lab3 and the LogDestination is set to syslog. Should I just change it back to file?
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535568628091,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17422","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I certainly prefer the file logging because the resulting logs include logger names. But I guess I need to learn to live with what syslog provides, since that is what we'll be getting from fielded installations.

At any rate, don't change it back to file until Jerry has had a chance to verify my 11:38 change, otherwise he will still see a control.log file and think my change didn't work.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535568928814,"updated":1535567936289,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17426","author":"ajones","authorFullName":"Aaron Jones","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
OK
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535569791843,"updated":1535568628091,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17447","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Aaron Jones, since the syslog destination will be the production configuration, I think we should leave it that way in Lab 3 and Paradise. But I also think it is important to have the logger names in the log file (my only reason for preferring the "file" destination to the "syslog" destination). So I created ST-786.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535640190097,"updated":1535568928799,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17453","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Obsolete due to ST-786.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535650561557,"updated":1535563862838,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]}],"tag":[]}, {"id":"ST-242","entityId":"64-7244","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"ST"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"242"},{"name":"summary","value":"Resume Broken"},{"name":"description","value":"
Noticed today on Sabretooth SabretoothInst-6.03.59.01 2017.12.22.0336.exe

Imported & ran the attached PDF

10:41:00 - Start job. Everything seems to run normal. Laser is engraving (all good)

10:45:00 - Pause job. Job pauses (takes about 3 clicks to get job to pause), XY returns home (good)

10:48:00 - Resume job attempted. Click resume job but job does not resume. First message (001.png) is "recent settings require job to be restarted" - no changes were made. Job was simply paused then resume was attempted. Clicked resume again (002.png) and got message unable to pause job (which actually makes sense due to the fact the job has been lost at this point the job must be restarted to be able to be paused again.
"},{"name":"created","value":"1513965217997"},{"name":"updated","value":"1515101216770"},{"name":"updaterName","value":"jsnead"},{"name":"updaterFullName","value":"Jerry Snead"},{"name":"resolved","value":"1514500466871"},{"name":"reporterName","value":"jsnead"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Jerry Snead"},{"name":"commentsCount","value":"7"},{"name":"votes","value":"0"},{"name":"links","value":[{"value":"ST-223","type":"Relates","role":"relates to"}]},{"name":"Priority","value":["Critical"],"valueId":["Critical"],"color":{"bg":"#ffc8ea","fg":"#444"}},{"name":"Type","value":["Bug"],"valueId":["Bug"],"color":null},{"name":"State","value":["Verified"],"valueId":["Verified"],"color":{"bg":"#409600","fg":"#fff"}},{"name":"Assignee","value":[{"value":"jsnead","fullName":"Jerry Snead"}]},{"name":"Milestone","value":["2017 12 29"],"valueId":["2017 12 29"],"color":null},{"name":"attachments","value":[{"value":"control.log","id":"70-5934","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/control.log?file=70-5934&c=true"},{"value":"16 Color Raster.pdf","id":"70-5935","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/16%20Color%20Raster.pdf?file=70-5935&c=true"},{"value":"001.png","id":"70-5936","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/001.png?file=70-5936&c=true"},{"value":"002.png","id":"70-5937","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/002.png?file=70-5937&c=true"}]}],"comment":[{"id":"69-11803","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-242","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Jerry Snead, Should I assume until told otherwise that you have all of the extra USB hubs daisychained between the PC and the laser system?
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1513967773827,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-11804","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-242","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Tim Crews Correct. I have three USB hubs inline between the USB from the XLS and the NUC.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1513968081632,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-11806","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-242","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
After importing the job, it looks like you changed the raster stroke option. Once you started the job, the software should set that value as the "reference" value. Instead, when you resumed the job, it still thought the raster stroke option was changed, and insisted on restarting the job.

Besides that, it absolutely should not take three tries to pause the job. I'll add a note to JUB-730 indicating that you are still running into this problem.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1513969609685,"updated":1513967773819,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-11837","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-242","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I fixed this. To verify, I suggest:
  • Import the 16-color raster job.
  • Before running the job, change the raster margin setting.
  • Run the job. The raster margin setting that you selected before running the job should be stored as the "reference" raster setting, not the raster margin setting that was in effect just after you imported the job.
  • Pause the job.
  • Resume the job. It should resume without telling you that the job needs to be restarted. That's because your current raster margin settings are the same as they were when you started the job.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1514500462752,"updated":1513969609680,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-11878","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-242","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Cannot check this one right now:
1. Black is not being imported (ST-256)
2. Unable to change available colors (14 in available, blue in db vector mark) to DB Raster (JUB-784)
3. If custom raster is attempted, the laser settings will not be held (JUB-786)

Currently no way to run the 16 color raster job at this juncture.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1514928643365,"updated":1514928879733,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-11925","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-242","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Verified as fixed with Windows Jubilee. Unable to check in Linux (JUB-794) - will check Linux when that bug is fixed and then mark this bug as verified fixed overall.

Am assigning to myself as reminder to check this when JUB-794 is fixed.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1515084722108,"updated":1514928643360,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-11952","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-242","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Due to all of the critical linux jubilee issues it is pretty hard to set up a job to test this in Linux. I was able to finally import the bear.pdf and test this out. Verified fixed on Linux Jubilee as well.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1515101216771,"updated":1515084722101,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]}],"tag":[]}, {"id":"ST-230","entityId":"64-7200","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"ST"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"230"},{"name":"summary","value":"Air will not stay on."},{"name":"description","value":"
@ about 10:18, I tried several times to start the job. Got message that if one process was air assist then all must be. I went back and DB Raster (Black) was not set to air. I turned it on and pressed play and got same message. Air was turned off on this color again. Finally the system caught up I guess and the job started running.

Jerry Snead, I think we have enough log data now to debug this problem; Austyn Bontrager has a potential fix in the works. It certainly does look like this issue is just another occurrence of the same problem.

If our theory is correct, as a workaround, restarting Jubilee should speed things back up for a while.
